concepts.subject: Mathematics
concepts.name: Slope-Intercept Interpretation
concepts.learningTarget: Explain what slope and intercept mean in context
concepts.keyIdea: In y = mx + b, m is rate of change and b is starting value.
questionStems: A model is written as y = mx + b. Which statement correctly interprets m and b?
Which interpretation of y = mx + b is mathematically valid in real-world modeling?
correctStatements: m shows how much y changes for each 1-unit increase in x, while b is y when x = 0.
m is the constant rate of change, and b is the initial value.
misconceptions: m is always the y-value when x = 0, and b is the rate of change.
m and b are both starting values with no effect on trend.
b controls slope while m only shifts the graph vertically.
applications: Use the slope to compare growth speed between two linear models.
Use the intercept to estimate a baseline before changes begin.
challengePrompts: Choose the strongest reason why slope is useful for prediction over long intervals.
hints: Match the equation term with graph behavior: tilt versus vertical start.

concepts.subject: Mathematics
concepts.name: Domain and Range Constraints
concepts.skill: Analyze valid input and output sets
concepts.learningTarget: Identify restrictions that make a function meaningful
concepts.keyIdea: Domain lists allowed inputs; range lists resulting outputs.
questionStems: What is the best distinction between domain and range of a function?
In modeling, why must domain be checked before interpreting outputs?
correctStatements: Domain is the set of possible inputs, while range is the set of resulting outputs.
Checking domain prevents using input values that make the model invalid.
misconceptions: Domain and range are interchangeable names for outputs.
Range is chosen first, then domain is forced to match without restrictions.
Any real number can be used as input for every function model.
applications: Exclude impossible time values like negative hours in growth models.
Restrict outputs when interpreting population models with practical limits.
challengePrompts: Pick the argument that best explains why context can shrink mathematical domain.
hints: Think input first, then output produced from that input.

concepts.subject: Physics
concepts.name: Velocity as Rate of Position Change
concepts.learningTarget: Differentiate speed and velocity in one dimension
concepts.keyIdea: Velocity includes direction; speed is magnitude only.
questionStems: Which statement about velocity is scientifically correct?
Why is direction essential when reporting velocity?
correctStatements: Velocity describes how position changes per unit time and includes direction.
Two objects can have the same speed but different velocities if directions differ.
misconceptions: Velocity and speed are always identical because both use distance and time.
Velocity is only used when acceleration is zero.
Direction has no effect on motion analysis if speed is known.
applications: Use sign convention to detect reversal of motion.
Compare average velocity over displacement, not total path length.
challengePrompts: Select the best critique of using speed instead of velocity in displacement problems.
hints: Ask whether the quantity can be positive or negative due to direction.

concepts.subject: Physics
concepts.name: Net Force and Acceleration
concepts.learningTarget: Relate mass, net force, and acceleration
concepts.keyIdea: Acceleration is proportional to net force and inversely proportional to mass.
questionStems: Which statement best matches Newton's Second Law?
How does changing mass affect acceleration if net force stays constant?
correctStatements: For constant mass, larger net force produces larger acceleration.
If net force is fixed, increasing mass decreases acceleration.
misconceptions: Mass and acceleration increase together under the same net force.
An object moving fast must have a large net force acting on it.
No acceleration can occur unless velocity is already high.
applications: Explain why loaded carts accelerate less than empty carts with same push.
Predict acceleration direction from net force direction.
challengePrompts: Choose the strongest evidence that net force, not speed, controls acceleration change.
hints: Focus on what causes change in motion, not motion value alone.

concepts.subject: Chemistry
concepts.name: Electron Arrangement
concepts.skill: Connect electron arrangement to chemical behavior
concepts.keyIdea: Valence electrons determine bonding tendencies and reactivity patterns.
questionStems: Why are valence electrons important in chemistry?
Which statement correctly links valence electrons and bonding?
correctStatements: Valence electrons participate most directly in chemical bonding.
Elements with similar valence patterns often show similar chemical behavior.
misconceptions: Core electrons mostly determine bonding because they are closer to nucleus.
All electrons contribute equally to reactivity in ordinary reactions.
Valence electrons matter only for ionic compounds, not covalent ones.
applications: Use valence count to predict likely ion charge.
Compare periodic groups to infer similar reactivity trends.
challengePrompts: Pick the best explanation for why group trends support valence-electron logic.
hints: Think about which electrons are easiest to gain, lose, or share.

concepts.subject: Chemistry
concepts.name: Mole Ratio Reasoning
concepts.skill: Use balanced equations as proportional maps
concepts.keyIdea: Balanced coefficients provide fixed mole ratios between substances.
questionStems: What does a balanced equation coefficient primarily represent?
Why are mole ratios central in stoichiometric calculations?
correctStatements: Coefficients indicate relative moles of reactants and products.
Mole ratios allow conversion from one substance amount to another.
misconceptions: Coefficients represent atomic mass of each substance.
Mole ratios are optional if equation is already balanced.
Conservation applies to volume only, not amount of substance.
applications: Convert known reactant moles to expected product moles.
Check whether reactant amounts can fully consume each other.
challengePrompts: Choose the best justification for using mole ratios before mass conversions.
hints: Read coefficients as a recipe ratio before doing arithmetic.

concepts.subject: Biology
concepts.name: Selective Permeability
concepts.skill: Relate membrane structure to transport behavior
concepts.learningTarget: Explain how cells regulate material movement
concepts.keyIdea: Cell membranes allow some substances through while restricting others.
questionStems: Which statement best explains selective permeability?
Why is selective permeability vital for cell survival?
correctStatements: Selective permeability helps maintain internal conditions required for life.
The membrane controls entry and exit of substances based on properties and transport mechanisms.
misconceptions: Cell membranes are fully open barriers to maximize exchange speed.
Only water can pass through membranes; all solutes are permanently blocked.
Permeability is fixed and cannot involve transport proteins.
applications: Predict osmotic effects when external solute concentration changes.
Explain how nutrient uptake can occur against concentration gradients.
challengePrompts: Select the best reason cells need both passive and active transport strategies.
hints: A living cell needs control, not unrestricted mixing.

concepts.subject: Biology
concepts.name: Alleles and Trait Expression
concepts.learningTarget: Differentiate inherited information from expressed trait
concepts.keyIdea: Genes can exist in variant forms called alleles that influence phenotype.
questionStems: What is the most accurate description of an allele?
How do alleles relate to trait variation?
correctStatements: Alleles are different forms of the same gene that can produce trait differences.
Genotype combinations of alleles influence observed phenotype.
misconceptions: Alleles are traits, while genes are proteins with no inheritance role.
Each person has only one allele for each gene in diploid organisms.
Phenotype always reveals genotype exactly without exceptions.
applications: Use allele notation to analyze simple inheritance patterns.
Distinguish carrier status from dominant trait expression.
challengePrompts: Choose the most defensible explanation for why phenotype may not uniquely identify genotype.
hints: Think of gene as location and allele as version at that location.

concepts.subject: Earth Science
concepts.name: Plate Boundary Interactions
concepts.learningTarget: Link boundary motion to geologic events
concepts.keyIdea: Different plate boundary motions produce characteristic landforms and hazards.
questionStems: Which statement correctly connects boundary motion and Earth process?
Why do convergent and divergent boundaries create different geologic outcomes?
correctStatements: Convergent boundaries commonly produce subduction, mountains, and strong seismic activity.
Divergent boundaries generate new crust as plates move apart.
misconceptions: Transform boundaries create new crust fastest due to sideways motion.
All volcanoes form only at divergent boundaries.
Plate boundaries are fixed lines with no relative movement over time.
applications: Infer earthquake risk from mapped plate boundary type.
Relate ocean ridge formation to divergent movement.
challengePrompts: Select the best argument for why one boundary type can host both earthquakes and volcanism.
hints: Track plate motion direction before predicting outcomes.

concepts.subject: Earth Science
concepts.name: Pressure and Wind Patterns
concepts.keyIdea: Air generally moves from high-pressure regions toward low-pressure regions.
questionStems: What is the main driver of horizontal wind movement?
Which explanation best links pressure gradients and weather changes?
correctStatements: Pressure differences drive wind from higher pressure to lower pressure areas.
Stronger pressure gradients generally produce stronger winds.
misconceptions: Wind always moves from low pressure to high pressure.
Pressure has little role in weather because temperature alone controls wind.
Calm weather means pressure is absent from the atmosphere.
applications: Use pressure maps to anticipate wind direction trends.
Relate rapidly changing pressure to potential storm development.
challengePrompts: Choose the strongest interpretation of why steep pressure gradients can signal hazardous weather.
hints: Think of air flow like balancing differences between regions.

concepts.subject: Computer Science
concepts.name: Algorithm Efficiency
concepts.learningTarget: Reason about performance as input size grows
concepts.keyIdea: Time complexity compares how running steps scale with input size.
questionStems: Why is asymptotic complexity useful when comparing algorithms?
Which statement best describes algorithmic efficiency analysis?
correctStatements: Complexity focuses on growth trend as input size becomes large.
An algorithm with slower growth can outperform others on large inputs.
misconceptions: Complexity only measures exact runtime on one computer setup.
If two algorithms solve the same task, growth rate differences do not matter.
Lower constant factors always beat lower growth rates for large inputs.
applications: Select scalable strategies for increasing dataset sizes.
Justify tradeoffs between implementation simplicity and long-term efficiency.
challengePrompts: Pick the best defense of using complexity classes in engineering decisions.
hints: Focus on trend with n, not one benchmark result.

concepts.subject: Computer Science
concepts.name: Stack vs Queue Behavior
concepts.skill: Select data structure by access rule
concepts.keyIdea: Stacks process last-in-first-out, while queues process first-in-first-out.
questionStems: Which statement correctly contrasts stacks and queues?
Why does access order matter when choosing between stack and queue?
correctStatements: Stacks remove the most recently added item first, queues remove the earliest added item first.
Choosing the wrong access rule can produce incorrect process behavior.
misconceptions: Stacks and queues are equivalent because both only add and remove elements.
Queues are LIFO while stacks are FIFO.
Access order rarely affects correctness, only memory usage.
applications: Use stack behavior for undo operations.
Use queue behavior for fair first-come task processing.
challengePrompts: Select the strongest argument for using queue semantics in scheduling systems.
hints: Track which item leaves first after multiple insertions.
